bunpro.writeup: In the same way as thecase marking particleとmeans 'and', sometimes it is translated as 'if'. In these cases, it is considered to be far stronger thanば,なら, orたら(which express hypothetical outcomes). This is because one of the primary uses ofとis highlighting aresult. In these cases,とis actually aconjunction particle, and shows one of three things.仮定の順接- A result that is assumed to be true, and obvious.確定の順接- A result that is known to be true.仮定の逆接- The opposite of a result that is assumed to be true.Due to this, the (B) part of a phrase usingとas 'if', will always occur when (A) happens, as it is considered to be the result of (A).とmay not be used in situations where the (B) result 'might' happen. It must be definite (or close to definite).In this particular nuance ofと, despite being translated as 'if', the actual meaning is much closer to 'and', asとis expressing that (A) and (B) will always go together.

examples.japanese: 甘いものをいっぱい食べると、太る。
examples.english: If you eat a lot of sweet things, you will gain weight.

examples.japanese: 部屋が汚いと、お母さんに怒られる。
examples.english: If my room is messy, my mother will yell at me.

examples.japanese: 部屋が静かだと、眠れない。
examples.english: If my room is quiet, I can't sleep.

examples.japanese: 地下鉄だと、5分早く着く。
examples.english: If it's the subway, you will arrive 5 minutes faster.
If I run, I will injure myself. (Unnatural Japanese, unless this person always injures themselves while running for some reason)

examples.japanese: 目を閉じると、何も見えない。
examples.english: I close my eyes, and I can't see.

examples.japanese: 勉強をすると、テストは簡単になる。
examples.english: If you study, the test will be easy.

examples.japanese: この石を磨くと、綺麗になる。
examples.english: If you polish this rock, it will become beautiful.

examples.japanese: ここから見ると、富士山が全然見えない。
examples.english: If you look from here, you can't see Mt. Fuji at all.

examples.japanese: 水着を持って来るのを忘れると海に入れないよ。
examples.english: If you forget to bring your swimsuit, you won't be able to swim in the ocean.

examples.japanese: 週に3回トレーニングをするとだんだん強くなる。
examples.english: Whenever you workout three times a week, you gradually get stronger. (if...)

dojg.description: A subordinate conjunction which marks a condition that brings about an uncontrollable event or state.

examples.japanese: (ks).ニューヨークに行くと面白い店が沢山ある・あります。
examples.english: If you go to New York, there are many interesting shops.

examples.japanese: (a).それは先生に聞くとすぐ分かった。
examples.english: I understood it immediately when I asked my teacher.

examples.japanese: (b).タイヤは古いと危ないですよ。
examples.english: Tires are dangerous if they are old.

examples.japanese: (c).魚が嫌いだと日本へ行った時困りますか?
examples.english: If you don't like fish, will you have trouble when you go to Japan?
If you are a student, there is a discount.
